comments.commentBody:
As Gail Collins writes, Sessions gives out with more of his smiles and wee soft words, emphasizing deftly that we are talking merely about brief little chats with a chubby ambassador. The regular, harmless fluffy social stuff of life in Washington, right.

Sessions and Trump and all the others obviously take us for fools. You CAN deceive all the people and convince them to cheer you onward. Or, just as worse, sell the people on going on with their happy lives and leave you to do what you want.
"just as worse"--the latest addition to "The Department of Redundancy Department

(It is also a parallel of bits of the Canterbury Tales, where Chaucer, in relating tales told by strangers from up north, cites their dialect both for pronunciation and vocabulary. Scholars of Middle English are thrilled that Chaucer did this, providing huge clues to the enormous shifts in pronunciation, lexicon and usage that were underway in that time. So with Dante here - his Inferno provides clues to the differentiation ongoing between French, Italian, Provençal and the mother tongue Latin.)

Trump dismissed this advice from the Kenyan knowing full well the real threat to our precious bodily fluids is vaccines. The older I get the harder it becomes to believe I can outlive these cruel numskulls who are occupying my government.
Sorry, anti-vaxers are everywhere, far too many among Democrats too. This foolishness is not partisan.

1. President Obama is not a Kenyan. You, with your name could be a Russian.
2. All unvaccinated people should be forbidden access to all public facilities until vaccinated. No jobs, no schools, no entertainment facilities. If a child who for medical reasons (only) catches a disease from an unvaccinated person (child or adult), & sustains permanent harm or death, the family of the "carrier" should have to turn all assets (no matter how big or small) over to the family. And then be sent to an area set aside for the purposely unvaccinated (desert of Arizona maybe) to live, permanently. If you feel your family is more important than anyone else's & it causes harm, it should cost you & yours everything. Since most anti-vac people are middle class that just might catch their attention.
Now, are we going to take care of our own mess first? The moron just announced, with no proof (normal for him), that the Obama Administration tried to do a Nixon/Watergate thing on trump tower. It is way past time to do something about this cretin, & his fanatics (fan is short for fanatic, bozos).

There is a very real risk that Trump will launch a military action against North Korea to "distract" attention from his domestic Russiagate political quick sand.
How do we protect ourselves from an incompetent egomaniac leader holding the nuclear codes AND the equally unbalanced North Korean leader?
These are not good circumstances.

"Do people think they are really going to commit suicide by pre-emptively striking?" Given that Kim Jong-un has killed family and hundreds of other people he does not trust, the answer is most definitely yes.

Foreign policy by Twitter probably offers limited potential for long-term success. Perhaps a cyber initiative to counter President Trump's injudiciously splenetic tweets might be a good place to start a reconsidered strategy to confront the growing North Korean threat.

www.endthemadnessnow.org

You apparently did not read the article. The Obama administration was using the military's large and growing cyber capability to attack North Korea's missile program in the only sane approach possible at this time.

I suppose you would like President Cheeto Benito to just start blasting away with missile strikes, hoping to accidentally hit the right targets. He did reference blowing the Russian spy ship off the U.S. coastout of the water, even though it was in international waters, and those transits are quite common for the past 40 years.

Our president is a monkey with a machine gun, so perhaps you'll get your wish.

"Three years ago, President Barack Obama ordered Pentagon officials to step up their cyber and electronic strikes against North Korea’s missile program in hopes of sabotaging test launches in their opening seconds."

How useful would crude missiles be with a developed counter missile defense?

Also part of the challenge is that his initial anti-Chinese posture was to manipulate the Chinese into issuing him the patents to his name, which he had been attempting to secure for many years. He succeeded. His attention is chronically diverted, rather than fully focused on the country.

That is a severe misreading of history and the article. The real ramp up in capabilities came after we stopped talking to them, under W. Prior to that, Clinton had managed to halt processing of uranium but the Horth Koreans cheated on plutonium.

No question Trump is planning a major cruise missile strike. The question I have is who is going to pay for the clean up? Here we go again- Flint, Michigan needs a $1 billion dollar water system and now the United States would have to build a new for North Korea? Blow the place to stone age and let South Korea and China clean up the mess.

The problem with the secret cyber strikes is that the public wouldn't know about it. Nothing excites Trump more than publicly bullying little guys. Look for him to take a more public approach that will probably end in disaster.

Good point. There's much done in secret (that we don't know about). Often the ground is prepared in secret and over time for an overt action, or events are forestalled in secret.

Global secret services, in tune with integrated cyber-service and diplomatic service, work 24/7 on their priorities. The job is to 1) affect events so the military is not needed and 2) advance national interest.

Trumpski is such that he'd tweet all to the world so he'd feel important and relevant for a day.

If that caused a problem he'd blame someone else. Like a 5-year old, the Poodle acts like the most entitled person on the planet. He's a moving train wreck who never once in his life accepted responsibility for anything.

A secretive, paranoid, erratic, unpredictable, authoritarian, corrupt leader with access to a nuclear arsenal. It's frightening. And on top of that we have to trust him to forge a rational policy against Kim Jong-un.
Maybe they'll become BFFs.

Was the US successful in sabotaging North Korea's missile tests? If yes, should that not be considered an act of war against a sovereign nation? Back in 2014, North Korea is said to have hacked into Sony, and that did not sit well with Americans.

Sure, we will say that North Korea is a threat to world peace and must not be allowed to develop ICBM's. But North Korea and some other nations may believe the US is the threat to world peace, and nations must arm against it.

That's part of this article. North Korea will now try to shrink the size of it's warhead to fit on developed ICBM. The time to act is now. The question is what the action is. There are no good options.

What frightens me right now is that Trump would use a nuclear attack as a way to distract from his Russia problems.  I'm totally serious because that's how his mind works, and the fact we have no adults in charge in the Cabinet or GOP Congress magnifies the problem.  God save us.

In a global world, unless the US, China and Russia put their heads together and solve the problem we're all losers. Trump is going to have too change is his attitude, the problem is not going to be solved on a tweet, than again it  could very well end on one.

The anti Obama tone of these comments are a sad commentary on the rabid ignorance of the right. Quite consistent though with obama derangement syndrome, and their rejection of reconstruction. Sorry boys, the dream of a white man's republic died at Appomattox

Rhporter - "The anti Obama tone of these comments are a sad commentary on the rabid ignorance of the right."

"President Barack Obama ordered Pentagon officials to step up their cyber and electronic strikes against North Korea’s missile program in hopes of sabotaging test launches in their opening seconds." I guess you think this was an excellent idea? I guess you think that conducting cyber-sabotage against an extremely unstable nuclear power and then admitting that you did it, is a good thing?

Your last sentence was not only unnecessary but extremely disgusting, and racist. When you and your ilk realize that fact you will be on your way to knowing why you lost almost 1000 elected positions during the past eight years.

China will never abandon North Korea.  Its recent cutoff of coal imports from North Korea appears to be less than hoped.  North Korea will continue to develop missiles and nuclear weapons.  Iran will eventually do the same.  Nuclear weapons will continue to proliferate despite the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, to which neither Israel, Pakistan, nor India have signed, and from which North Korea has withdrawn.  It is just a matter of time until a nuclear-armed missile attack is launched.  The threat from nuclear weapons makes terrorism seem like a kindergarten fight.  I fear too few leaders are willing and able to do anything to stem this tide.

China will never do the US bidding on N. Korea. It might however deal, if it gets something from the deal, and if it is left in control of how it handles N. Korea.

China could hardly do worse with Kim than we have.

China has limits it has made clear. It wants the US kept far from China's Yalu border. It wants a soft collapse without mass refugee flows. We can offer those things.

Our friends in South Korea would approve. They see the North as their cousins, as family, and they literally are. They don't want a hard collapse either. They also would be quite pleased to reduce the dangers and costs of defense that burden them.

This could be done. It has not even been properly explored.
No more comment or speculation, a massive pre-emptive strike and/or assassination of the whole NK leadership is now the only way out of this totally unacceptable situation.

That strike would mean the end of south korea. Don't you think we would have done that already, otherwise? Sheesh....

The only solution is actually to take a very very large financial hit and basically pay China to resolve the NK issue. I'm talking giving them a trillion dollars or something on that order. They are afraid that if they let the NK situation deteriorate, they will need to subsidize the people of NK for years. We pay them to do it, and they might do it. It's literally the only way to avoid a massive massive death count.

That is a recipe for disaster.

Anything that would come out right would require far more sophistication.

I described the options, not how they should be planned and carried out. That is for those whose job it is to implement them. If we let madmen have their way there will be no end to it. Of course there will be a price to pay but better that than cringe in the face of evil. The same applies to the Teheran Mullahs and their missile program.

The only American option is China. Nothing really the US can do short of an invasion which is not an option. China has to be told in no  uncertain terms solve this problem. Basically China has to take him out.
We cannot count on China to take him out. We need to grow up and solve our own problems.

The con man is too busy preening and putting on primetime "speech-shows" to care about anything more important than himself or lying and cheating the American people out of their money.  His egregious lack of experience and disregard for the danger our enemies pose is dangerous in and of itself.  Most of the country wants him removed immediately, and the rest are so angry and deluded, they would happily put a baboon in his place.  His removal is the only thing our country should be thinking about and accomplishing.  Each day he's in "office," he makes a mockery of our Constitution and our precious democracy.
Yes there is a sense of urgency here. Once events tip everything over the edge, it is too late. I wish your country well.

I'm no fan of Trump, but on this issue I don't think it's fair to knock him. This is an inherited issue, with no really good options. The choice really comes down to double down on dubious technology, or military strikes. ISIS is not an exestensial threat. It seems like North Korea is. I'm no hawk, but in this particular case, I would lean towards surgical strikes. Based on this article, there isn't enough intel for that option. Hoping Trump picked the right security advisors to get us though this delema.

Its way past the time we realize it is not a matter of if but when some lunatic is going to use a nuclear device on a major city resulting in mass casualties not seen since the firebombing and atomic weapons use during WW2.  Increasingly, it is looking as if that lunatic will likely be Donald Trump, and if the disastrous attack he ordered in Yemen is any example he won't have a clue about the consequences he will be getting us into.

At worst, the Yemen attack was a Bay of Pigs fiasco that was left to him, which he failed to stop.

That is not a fair attack from those who left it to him.

Also, nuclear use was not confined to ideas coming from Trump. That accusation comes from those who were themselves presenting that very danger, using language that was at least as reckless in support of policies far more reckless, people with a history of failures by half considered overreaching such as Libya, Syria, and Ukraine.

This complaint aimed at Trump is purely partisan, coming from those with that in their own background.

I'd rather we urge caution, and a diplomatic approach via outreach, which is exactly what the anti-Trump attacks seem designed to prevent.

That is not to suggest Trump is any paragon. We've hit bottom after dodging the worst bullet. Now we need to crawl out, and it will be a long crawl requiring far better from people less compromised.

North Korea should be his most urgent problem but it turns out that a more pressing concern is the warfare declared and begun by Democrats to satisfy the demands of the base to undermine the President at every turn and in every way. This is McConnell times fifty.

It’s incredible how GOP backers supported all out political war and obstructionism against the Obama Administration for 8-years; and now cry fowl if fire is returned by the Democrats. The hypocrisy of the GOP at the time was obvious, now it is stunning.

Totally lost on the GOP is that the party abandoned governing for the good of all the people long ago. If Trump and the GOP wish that we constructively work together for the good of the country and stop the partisan warfare, which they started, action speaks louder than words. The day Mr. Bluster, Confrontation and Chaos embraces this approach I think then, and only then, will Democrats respond in kind. Playing nice with this POTUS and his band of radicals whose goal is to dismantle the US Government is ludicrous.

Those are not "demands of the base." They are the excuses of the status quo, trying to keep power.

The danger is not just of distraction. It is even more of distortion.

Wars have come of political leaders acting out for domestic reasons. We are creating a situation in which Trump is pushed to prove something by acting. Any possible actions will serve the interests of the War Party portion of those pushing him.

Our domestic politics are likely to show their distorting effects on our most serious problems, because those are the ones to come up. North Korea is a dangerous example.

I'm convinced that the least imperfect answer for North Korea involves doing a deal with China. The current events are foreclosing such deals, in fact are meant by too many doing them to foreclose such deals, what they see not as a flaw but as a feature.

I'm betting we never heard about, "warfare declared and begun by [Republicans] to satisfy the demands of the base to undermine the President at ever turn and in every way," from you back when Obama was dealing with this same issue and others more pressing to the needs of people of this country, like healthcare, huh?  I'll also bet you loved McConnell back then.  But you tell me.  Trump is a big boy, now, since Tuesday, at least, and if he can't take the heat from the opposition, he needs to get out of the kitchen.  Today, would be fine with me.
